												SHORT VERSION: The free-roam, Mount&Blade-style RPG part of the game is decent (although simplistic... there are way too few stats and skills, for instance), but the combat system of this combat-centred game is irredeemably flawed. With too few tactical options and somewhat unclear rules, it fails to impress and STRONGLY encourages save-scumming. All in all, the game’s neither good nor bad - an okay-ish, relaxing experience that I (unfortunately) cannot wholeheartedly recommend, not for the full price. 5+/10 or 6/10 at best.LONG VERSION: The combat lacks depth. Let’s define depth as “the number of meaningful choices a player can make at any given moment”. If you consider that a.) you can’t freely move the units, b.) you can only attack the nearest enemy unit and c.) there are hardly any special attacks, abilities etc., the player often feels like there’s very little he can change (it feels almost like auto-resolve at times, you just do the clicking, not the decision-making). For example, if you have a warrior (a young noble, let’s say) and it’s his turn, you can only do 3 things (apart from drinking a potion): attack the nearest foe, postpone the attack on said foe or skip his turn entirely in exchange for a defence bonus in the next turn. There should be more tactical options like:- special attacks (e.g. a shield bash that does little to no damage, but lowers the defence of the target so that you could have a specialized character with high initiative that would make the enemy vulnerable to your slower (low initiative), but hard-hitting characters),- will points (limited points that you can use up to make the attacks stronger or more accurate or whatever; it worked great in The Banner Saga, why not here?),- flanking mechanics, defence penalties for being attacked by several enemies and, generally speaking, the ability to move your troops more freely (even if there’s a penalty for that); seriously, why do I have mounted troops if I can’t go behind the enemy line and kill that pesky healer in turn 1? That’s what cavalry does, flank and charge,- more “spells” (or at least alternative, stronger versions of the same “spells” which you have to “charge up” for a turn and which can fail if the caster takes damage in the meantime),Imagine for a moment that we have all these options. I just lost a battle, what do I do? Fight again and try a different approach, move my troops differently, defend my crossbowman this time, use up all the will points to eliminate that mystic as quickly as possible, or lower the defence of that tank-ish knight with a special attack etc. Lots of possibilities, as you can see. Now back to reality. I just lost a battle in Legends of Eisenwald, what do I do? Reload the game, ask myself why I failed and SAVE-SCUM by using that knowledge to modify my army (shift their initial positions, give some weapons or armour to different people, go back to a village to buy a potion or recruit a different person). See the difference? It’s breaks the immersion if your character is a psychic who can predict what will happen next :)So I’m not saying there’s no depth to the combat system. The problem is that the meaningful choices occur BEFORE the battle. Once you engage in combat, there’s very little you can do to change the outcome. And for me, that’s not much fun at all. I watched combat videos made by the devs to see if the situation changes in the mid- and late-game, but no, it doesn’t.Also, as I already mentioned, the game doesn’t make the rules clear enough. Why does the spearman sometimes counterattack and sometimes he doesn’t? Is there any defence penalty from being surrounded? Why can I sometimes choose the direction of the attack and sometimes I can’t? And so on.When it comes to the RPG elements, I didn’t play the game long enough to say anything about the story, but as I said, there are too few stats and skills for the game to actually FEEL like an RPG. Also, there’s no character creation whatsoever, which is sad. You can only choose the class and change the name so you don’t have to play as Heinrich.Overall, it’s not a bad game and some people will find it pretty fun (might as well give it a try when it's on sale and, if you feel about the combat system the way I do, you can always get a refund...). Personally, I may play it for a few more hours, but I have to say I’m disappointed (I was waiting for this game when it was still in early access). Too bad, because it definitely had potential.

YouTube™ Video: Legends Of Eisenwald Review 

			Views: 5,595		

			Cosmic reviews Legends of Eisenwald a indie RPG with tactical battles and strategy elements developed by Aterdux entertainment. This games was provided free of charge for the purpose of critique.		

The combat is a simple turn based hex system that simply requires you to attack and defend. The combat is the biggest let down of the entire game. Unlike most turn based combat games, you don’t have freedom of movement. Instead you can only move when you want to attack a target. There’s no tactical positioning or moving your units out of range of archers. All that is every required in combat is a few simple clicks and while there are unit abilities and some spells, there is very little in terms of actual tactical depth. The sheer lack of freedom of movement in the combat can really hinder you at points, it means you can’t have your spearman on the right flank just move over to the left to defend against a mounted foe, instead the enemies closest to them, even if they are a couple of hexes away must be cleared out first.The over world works in real time, as you move so do others, time can be stopped, slowed or sped up at convenience. The overworld brings back found memories of the Heroes of Might and Magic series, legends pulls it all of well, with great landscapes and graphical assets. While the movement is slow, the developers have done a good job of making the world look alive. Characters have different routines, which are also affected by quests and the day/night cycle. For example, if you’re hunting down a thief, it’s likely you won’t find him during the day. Instead you’ll have to lay in wait, fast forward time and wait for him to come out at night. The movement is fairly slow on the overworld which can get pretty irritating when you’re trying to catch up with a certain character.The questing in Legends is a mixed bag of both relatively ok quests and some that are fairly tedious endeavors. The major issue for me was the lack of any meaningful choice system in the game which I certainly felt was due to the lack of creativity quest wise. The majority of main quests consist of running around to talk to a few people and a fight and that’s it, it’s all pretty much rinse and repeat after that in various forms. Questing in legends provides a shallow experience, there’s really very little depth to it, however what it lacks in quality it makes up in quantity. There’s a lot to do in the game and some of it I had no idea what I was supposed to be doing. This was thanks the vague quest instructions, which don’t get me wrong, I love figuring things out for myself and dislike games that hand hold the entire way through, however the obscurity of the quests were bad and artificially elongated quests that would have otherwise been very short, it also adds artificial difficulty to simple things.Now like I mentioned the games story isn’t bad if you can forgive the odd writing at times. However with there are a couple of uncomfortable moments by modern standards in there such as some remarks against Jews that certainly could be considered as Anti-sematic, do I think the developers are racist? No of course not. It’s clear they tried to reflect the times however the small remarks to other races add nothing to the actual setting and story and could have gone amiss.Graphically, Legends of Eisenwald does well, it’s not terrible to look at and the character models are done fairly well. The character animations look off and janky on occasion particularly in combat. The art style of the game could have done with a little more color as everything is done in a dark shade of color with little actual vibrancy. It’s not that a darker tone is bad, it’s that mixed with the shallow mechanics, it makes the game look bland and ugly in places, when it doesn’t need to be. The most disappointing side of the art was the lack of character assets with soldiers all looking like clone troopers from star wars. Each character looks of that class looks the exact same, for example three monks are identical clones which breaks any and all immersion when in combat. The soundtrack of the game isn’t bad but doesn’t particularly stand out in anyway, the only thing that did stand out about the audio was the few bugs that would cause the audio to go off.Overall Legends of Eisenwald has a lot of content but lacks any depth to its mechanics. It’s rough around the edges but does hold a certain charm to it. It’s certainly entertaining and packs plenty of hours in there to get your monies worth. I think people looking for an RPG with more depth to progression, combat and certainly a better quality story may wish to wait for a sale before buying Legends

												Clunky; is how best to describe this game.I had forgotten about this title all together having bought it way back in 2014/5 on pre release. I liked the way it was developing and looked forward to a rich story driven adventure collecting companions and wondorous equipment along the way. Sadly it isnt very different from what i can tell from pre release other than there is more of it and in truth it was a little dated in terms of game design back in 2014 but I thought it looked like it was going to have some new innovative ideas but once again sadly this appears not to be the case in fact there are some awful design choices in the game.The map you trundle around on......you can't actually pan around. You have to click somewhere along the route to get to where you want to go. Want to click on the map in the corner to set a destination......sorry no. Want to move around the map to look for something......sorry no. Want to drudge around drearily to your next possible destination only to figure out that it was on the other side of the map......yes you can do that a lot.In combat for example you cannot move tactically; you can only move towards the nearest enemy. If your archer is engaged in melee with someone with a shield they cant hit them unless they have a skill to overmatch. Your healers/priests/rear line do not even have a weapon to attack with in melee. Healing is next to useless in a tactical sense as most armies/groups will kill at least one of your people before your healer gets a turn (a useful turn) The whole balance of the game feels very off; to start with you struggle very hard to gain xp and manage injuries and gold and then all of a sudden you are capturing castles and don't have a care about gold.......the xp is still an awful grind though. The story driven narative was interesting at first but eventually just turned into click click click what fetch and carry quest dear peasant would you have your mighty lord carry out for you today type of thing. Also the quests themselves can be quite baffling and the log is no help; vague is putting it midly. You simply only have to google the undead graveyard quest to see a litany of baffled seekers; one of which even trolls, and rightly so, one of the developers who decides to post in the thread. I will admit there is something about the game that keeps you playing but after the first chapter i just couldn't face the thought of levelling every sinlge character in my party again, despite figuring out how to use potions out of combat by this stage......there is no tutorial as such; wait there is it just doesnt cover things like potions. Oh yes they game on every new chapter strips you of items.......gold.......party members but you do get to keep your carry over on the final chapter from what im told. Can i skip ahead to that last chapter then so my hours of play don't feel like such a dissapointment every time i complete a chapter......sadly no you can'tThere are older and better games out there that do this better than this title; it had a lot of promise in pre release but sadly it never lived up to that promise.

												I really wanted to like this game but now I am just glad I bought it when it was on a -50% offer. Disappointed to say the least. The interface is retro and basic but it serves its purpose and is usable. The battles, when you get over the dodgy pathfinding/target selection issues are fine. Nothing revolutionary but how much can you improve a turn-based, hex-grid combat sequence? This game makes you work. Its not handed to you on plate. Neither does it treat you like an idiot.And, once I got over my initial pre-conceptions and actually got into the game, I enjoyed wandering around the map, fighting and exploring. So all in all it doesn't sound that bad right? Well, for me, the problem is all the hours I invested in building up a little force, equipping them, choosing upgrades and deciding which partciular career path they were going to take. Then, you complete the current mission and whammo! There you are........alone......... and almost penniless. Your team has gone! All that time and effort you put in was for absolutely nothing!Now you kinda anticipate that when you get to the next mission the baddies are going to be tougher and better equipped (this is a TBS game after all), so you naturally want to take your team so you can cope with next mission, yes? Wel, no. What happens is you are droppped into the next map with only your characters gear and enough money to buy a bowl of gruel, should you happen upon an establishment that sells bowls of gruel, which you won't. The very next mission sees me recruiting a base level healer and two pitchfork wielding peasants. Have a guess how long they lasted against the pursuing bandits. Not very long at all., They die. There's nowhere else to recruit anymore peasants from and there are several waves of bandits heading your way that you simply cannot escape. It is totally pointless.Like I said at the top of this review, I really did want to like this game. I'm long in the tooth as a gamer. I go back to 1993  and The commodore Amiga and TBS games are my thing. But this one, well, my advice is not to bother. And that is all I have to say.

												Legends of Eisenwald plays a little bit like King's Bounty, but unfortunately lacks some of the polishing (and a lot of game balance). That alone made this game a lot more frustrating, when making things just a bit easier or just a bit more apparent would have tipped the balance.The overhead map movement is an exercise in frustration because finding the correct path through the terrain isn't always immediately obvious. This led to a lot of pixel-hunting, something I thought we got rid of in the late 90s.UI is a bit of a mess, as well. One commenter noted that upgrading was a bit of a chore, since there isn't a way to figure out what unit upgrades do; unlike your hero upgrades, there's no tooltip to explain what an upgrade does, so choosing and saving/reloading was the norm. I stumbled upon this completely by accident, but right-clicking the upgrade tree for your units shows a tooltip of their upgraded abilities. I have no idea why this wasn't included in a regular hover tooltip, and this could have more clearly been highlighted in the tutorial.Finally, there are a lot of game moments where everything just feels unfair, without much warning. Spoiler alert: in the third act, you face zombies, which would be fine and dandy if I'd known that some units that are afraid of zombies will desert your army completely. I was put in an unwinnable situation since I'd chosen the ranged hero, and my whole front line disappeared. There isn't much build-up to this at all, and that alone put the stopper on any desire I had to play onwards.All in all, not recommended.

Early Access Review
								More reviews @ TheVideogameBacklog.comLegends of Eisenwald is said to be a Medieval Strategy RPG. On the surface it looks even better than I expected it to be. I mean, we are starting to see a lot of good-looking Early Access games, but still it surprises me. I do like myself a good tactics game as most of you well know, so I wasn’t about to pass this opportunity up.The main pull for myself to Legends of Eisenwald was the combat. That’s also the first disappointment as well. It’s on a hex system, but there’s not as much depth to the combat as I was hoping, but it is rather brutal and fast… kind of like a medieval skirmish would be I presume. You’ve got rear healers and buffs, then your ranged and then your “tanks”. I use air-quotes because as of writing this, really only my main dude is a tank. Everyone else is more like a meat-shield. You can either start to attack the top half or the bottom half with your main character if he’s in the middle as is the default, but everyone else just kind of moves forward to the guy closest to him. This is the fight. You can’t have everyone just jump to one guy at the beginning of the fight, but rather you are forced to fight the closest opponent. If realism was the intention, they got because that does make the most logical sense. Tactics-wise… you can’t change the positioning of your guys before the fight, but rather before you even enter the fight and see how they are aligned and then it’s too late. There are no obstacles, just people and it feels like a different combat system would have worked better here. Maybe a 2.5D isometric combat system?The main pull for myself to Legends of Eisenwald was the combat. That’s also the first disappointment as well. It’s on a hex system, but with no real depth. You’ve got rear healers and buffs, then your ranged and then your “tanks”. I use air-quotes because as of writing this, really only my main dude is a tank. Everyone else is more like a meat-shield. You can either start to attack the top half or the bottom half with your main character if he’s in the middle as is the default, but everyone else just kind of moves forward to the guy closest to him. This is the fight. You can’t have everyone just jump to one guy at the beginning of the fight, but rather you are forced to fight the closest opponent. If realism was the intention, they got because that does make the most logical sense. Tactics-wise… you can’t change the positioning of your guys before the fight, but rather before you even enter the fight and see how they are aligned and then it’s too late. There are no obstacles, just people and it feels like a different combat system would have worked better here. Maybe a 2.5D isometric combat system?The story is that you leave your home to go off somewhere and fight only to come back home and find that there is infighting at home. Lame, but dems the brakes. The writing and story in Legends of Eisenwald is pretty solid. I’ve enjoyed most of if not all that I’ve encountered so far. It’s both interesting and intriguing but it seems to be held back by the game proper. The quest log is somewhat useful, but not very. I was once told to go to the southern bridge near a watch tower… there wasn’t one. It will guide you to some places, but not all (which is fine, I can read, but still). You also don’t have too much money, but you’re told to go and hire people to help you out. They cost money per day, but that didn’t come off as obvious to me and I still don’t really see it anywhere listed. The button just says hire not pay this amount each day. (Goodbye money.)Legends of Eisenwald doesn’t feel too much like your traditional RPG either where you can go off and explore, killing bad guys for loot and money and generally getting the lay of the land. You need more money and I’m believing that is only going to happen while following the story. There is nothing wrong with a linear game, but Legend of Eisenwald doesn’t feel like it was intended to be that way. It gives the feeling like it was supposed to be more open. Maybe you just have to pay your dues and follow the story for it to open up to you later, but that’s not really how I play RPG’s. I wonder off and kill bad-guys and take their money… but the bad guys are mostly broke here.Score: Wait For Some UpdatesI don’t give this score lightly. I really wanted to give Legends of Eisenwald the better of the two impression scores, but while it has a lot of potential, I feel it will probably be more worth it after a few more updates. 												I recently received Legends of Eisenwald as part of the latest Humble Bundle. I was unfamiliar with it going in, but as a fan of classic turn based strategy games like Heroes of Might and Magic, Disciples, Warlords, and so on, I thought it would be worth giving this game a go. I'm now 10 hours into the game and on the third chapter of the campaign. There are definitely some rough edges here but I'm enjoying my time overall. On the negative side, the interface is a little buggy and obtuse. There is no easy way to compare the stats of two different items and considering the game is asking you to fully equip up to a dozen soldiers, that can make inventory management a bit frustrating. There are also a number of item abilities, but to my knowledge there is nowhere to go to see what effect an ability has. Some are obvious, such as one called something like Vampiric Touch. I can get a solid idea of what that does, but others are not as clear. More problematic, is that I also have been unable to find a way to look at the upgrade trees for various soldiers, making my choices pretty much random. And even when I have made a choice there is often little explanation of what has changed or improved with the upgrade. So poor inventory and stat management combined with a decent but not excellent translation (I assume from German) makes the game a bit hard to get into, but as someone who has been playing games for 25+ years, I can easily remember a time when every foreign game required a bit of guesswork, so that didn't bother me too much. That said, I can easily see how a less patient gamer might just end up giving up on this before they figured it out. Once you do get a hang of things most of the rest of the game is a big positive. You have a fair number of upgrade paths for your soldiers without things being overwhelming. You need to outfit your entire force but there doesn't seem to be an inventory limit so you are free to keep things for future use, and combat is tough, fun, and quick while not being too complex. There are also a ton of hidden secret areas in each level you can find that would earn you high quality gear if you go exploring. As a final note, numerous reviews here and on professional sites have said that the quest log is poor, but I have not found that to be the case. You can hit the magnifying glass on most any quest where you need to go to a specific location and have it mark it for you on your map. Others have said rumors aren't saved in your quest log, but that is also not true, they are just located under notes.Lastly, there is the debate about losing your soldiers and inventory at the end of each level. While standard practice in this type of game, traditionally you are allowed to choose a couple soldiers or items to keep and take with you to the next level. Here you just get your main character and whatever equipment he has on him at the time, which is fine but I would have liked to select one or two additional units to progress with me. As it is, you have to start your army from scratch each level, which can be a bit deflating. All told I would recommend this game to fans of classic TBS titles from the 90's, as well as any younger gamer who enjoys slower paced titles and is willing to put up with some rough edges they might not be accustomed to.

												Holy smokes this game is long. And I didn't even unlock the "secret", deeper endings. It has a polished lore, complex story and quite unique taste - I've never encountered a game with so many interesting legends, fables and stories - not only that, but majority of them is also connected to the core plot of the game!The game succeeds in making some interesting gameplay experiments which allow you to feel something very special. Just imagine: it’s a dark night. You, a betrayed knight/sorcerer/crossbow-female-knight, together with your servants and companions pass a lonely bench under a tree and get to a tavern. But there are no generic black-cloaked quest-givers inside, not at all. But there are common folks all around you and you start listening to what they have to say. Some peasant and mercenary talk about a knight who lives nearby – the peasant heard the knight keeps some weird barrels in his basement and the mercenary claims he knows what’s inside them. A peasant girl tells the innkeeper that apparently some other knight sleeps with his own sister, while the innkeeper claims he saw the same knight entering a brothel in nearby town. A monk tells the gathered people a legend about the saint man who is the patron of the local monastery while a drunk beggar talks to himself about a ghost which he believes he saw next to the ruined tower...The variety of side quests, main quests and level structures is impressive and often you have to figure out on your own if a legend has some truth in it or is just a silly gossip. The story is very complex and it tries to show every side of each story as grey and conflicting as possible. Even though the core story is mostly straight-forward and very tightly holds your hand, sometimes you have to make decisions and choices which most of the time feel as “judging what is the lesser evil”. Very rarely the game offers you an easy choice such as “do you prefer some amount of gold for doing something evil or more XP/an item for taking an extra mile to do the right thing?”. Most of the things you are going to do are neither right nor just, and sometimes not even that honorable. I like it a lot and it’s hard to not compare it to Game of Thrones and it’s mean-spirited portrayal of royal families as normal, weak people who always see themselves as heroes and find excuses for their bad deeds.However.The game has many flaws, some of them - major. UI is absolutely terrible and could be improved in so many obvious ways it gives me a headache. Multiple performance bugs can annoy and break the immersion, although not as much as the fact that through the entire game we control only 5-12 (rarely) people and with their help we destroy huge noble families, conquer castles, lands and so on (I don’t mind “unrealistic” approach, but it sometimes get rather silly). Some graphics are amazing, some are terrible. Sometimes music makes a fantastic atmosphere, yet sometimes it gets glitchy – a couple of songs play at the same time, volume spikes up and down and so on…It is very clear the developers had to make some budget cuts and had many interesting ideas which they couldn’t bring to their full potential because of lacking resources. A good example may be the watchtowers and outposts. These structures, once conquered, may become a defense posts for our army – we can keep in them our spare soldiers and try to stop some of the roaming A.I. (which has tendency to conquer our villages while we are on the opposite side of the map). However, transporting soldiers is an absolute pain in the♥♥♥♥♥since you have absolutely no extra space or tool to do that – if you want to have a filled watchtower, you have to go to a castle, leave there your soldiers, take spare soldiers, take them to the watchtower, go for new soldiers and also bring them to the watchtower, then you can take your own army back... It’s ridiculous and it feels like the developers just couldn’t create the entire balanced system of army management so they decided to leave it just like it is, even though it’s completely useless.The battle system is also far from perfect and it lacks “depth”. Once I got bored in managing my units I started to use the “automatic battle” option 95% of the time and thankfully the game handles it pretty well. Very rarely you face an enemy which you can defeat by strategy and not just by probability count introduced by the game. Many reviewers find the combat system the most important flaw of this game, so if you want to play this game mostly to lead your knights and soldiers to battle, you may be disappointed and I would suggest looking for a different title. The English translation sucks a lot. I’m not a native speaker myself but even I was often distracted by unnatural phrasing and generic mistakes. And there is A LOT of dialogue to read so a good editor is definitely not a part of the game where you should save a buck.-----TL;DR 7/10 is a fair rating, however there is lot in this game to love. I think it can satisfy most fans of medieval-fantasy RPG games (especially if they like games like “King's Bounty” or “HoM&M”), but there surely are some people who are going to be absolutely enchanted by everything this game has to offer - especially because of the clever writing. Judge yourself if you can forgive some bad gameplay decisions, poor UI and other mistakes.

												Being formulaic, think Heroes of Might and Magic meets Mount and Blade on semihistorical medieval Germany.This game is a unique gem, however. It mixes smart tactical combat, solid looting and leveling gameplay, good art, amazing music, a sense of immersion I struggle to find nowadays in games (I'm an older gamer) and an absolutely great story.The tactical combat looks  simple but surely it isn't. It is a smart and different take than HOMM series, as you have to act with your units, and move is a consequence of the attack order. Every action you have a series of decision to make and it is very interesting for a long time.If you are an experienced strategy gamer, however, if you don't go for the higher difficulties it could be a bit too easy, and after while it gets a bit repetitive, but until there it is very fun.The leveling and looting system makes managing your party interesting. There is a nice variety of loot and troops, and simple but rewarding upgrade trees. The story is top notch, though the storytelling is a bit lacking. Some say it is complicated and really is, you have to pay attention. I would say the story is on par with King of Dragon Pass. You don't have a lot of choices, though, as the story unfolds, but the quality makes for it. The worldbuilding is awesome as well, you really feels like you are in medieval Germany.At the end of the campaign the gameplay gets a bit repetitive, though, but is mostly a case of the campaigtn being too long than the gameplay being boring. I only kept going for the story.Overall, a great game. 8.5/10
